results.abstract: The history of the American spacesuit may be missing a chapter.
results.snippet: The history of the American spacesuit may be missing a chapter.
results.lead_paragraph: The history of the American spacesuit may be missing a chapter if NASA doesn't change its plans.

results.abstract: NASA is set to launch space shuttle Atlantis (M)

headline.main: After Setbacks, Shuttle Is Ready for Launching

results.snippet: NASA plans to launch the first shuttle mission of 2007 from the Kennedy Space Center at 7:38 p.m. Friday.
results.lead_paragraph: Three months after its external fuel tank took thousands of dings and pockmarks from the golf-ball-size hailstones of a freakish winter storm, the space shuttle Atlantis is ready to fly. NASA plans to launch the first shuttle mission of 2007 from the Kennedy Space Center at 7:38 p.m. Friday. The weather is expected to be very good, with just a 20 percent chance of a delay.

results.abstract: Kennedy Space Center opens $60 million Shuttle Launch Experience in Cape Canaveral, Fla, 44,000-square-foot building that holds four simulators, each of which can accommodate 44 people, taking them through special-effects heavy approximation of stages of space shuttle launching and ascent (M)

headline.main: For the Adventurous, an Earthbound Ride on the Shuttle

results.snippet: Hitching a ride on the space shuttle comes only to the lucky few, but the Kennedy Space Center has developed a ride that just may be the next best thing.
results.lead_paragraph: Hitching a ride on the space shuttle comes to the lucky few only after a long selection process and arduous training. But the Kennedy Space Center visitor complex has worked with current and former astronauts to develop a ride that just may be the next best thing. The $60 million Shuttle Launch Experience opened Memorial Day weekend. The 44,000-square-foot building holds four simulators, each of which can accommodate 44 people, taking them through a special effects-heavy approximation of the stages of launching and ascent.

results.snippet: Profiles of the astronauts aboard space shuttle Atlantis on a trip to the International Space Station.
results.lead_paragraph: Col. Frederick W. Sturckow, of the U.S. Marine Corps, goes by Rick or ''CJ,'' and was shuttle pilot on flights in 1998 and 2001. ''When I get back, all I can think about,'' he said, is '' when can I go do that again?'' NASA's training program is so extensive, he said, that he has told his crew that when they actually fly their mission, ''it's going to feel like we're in the simulator at the Johnson Space Center,'' he said. Using the abbreviation for simulation, he added, ''It's going to feel like we're going from one sim to the next for 12 days.''

results.abstract: Article on Largay Travel of Waterbury, Conn, which specializes in adventure vacations, and its president Paul Largay; agency is selling seats on Virgin Galactic's SpaceShipTwo, which is scheduled to begin suborbital flights from Mojave Desert in late 2009 for $200,000 each; photos (M)
results.lead_paragraph: CALLING all astronauts! To Waterbury? That's where Paul Largay, the president of Largay Travel, which specializes in adventure vacations, is selling seats on Virgin Galactic's SpaceShipTwo, scheduled to begin suborbital flights from the Mojave Desert to the fringe of space in late 2009.

results.abstract: Mission managers determine that fire alarm that sounded in Russian part of International Space Station on June 12 was result of software glitch (M)

headline.main: Glitch Blamed For Fire Alarm On Orbiter

results.snippet: Astronauts and mission managers scrambled on Tuesday when a fire alarm went off on the Russian part of the International Space Station.
results.lead_paragraph: Astronauts and mission managers scrambled yesterday when a fire alarm went off on the Russian part of the International Space Station. Within 20 minutes, however, the problem was determined to be a software glitch. After alarms clanged in the background and a Russian interpreter seemed to grow breathless trying to keep up with the stream of discussion on the alarm and the response, Clayton C. Anderson, an astronaut on the space station, called down to mission control and said, ''We looked around and smelled around,'' and found no evidence of fire.

results.abstract: Michael Kimmelman reviews 52nd Venice Biennale; photos (M)

headline.main: That Unruly, Serendipitous Show in Venice

results.snippet: Much of this biennale murmurs, it doesn’t shout. I doubt this fair will be recalled as groundbreaking or dynamic, but it is an independent show, strong in its convictions.

multimedia.caption: Serious Art
multimedia.credit: Michael Kimmelman, the chief art critic of The New York Times, discusses the Venice Biennale.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: Michael Kimmelman, the chief art critic of The New York Times, discusses the Venice Biennale.

results.lead_paragraph: After the artists, dealers, critics and hedge-fund guys jetted off last weekend to shop in Basel and check out Documenta in Germany, it became easier to tell whether the 52nd version of the Venice Biennale was as much of a bore as it seemed. It's not. It's subtle and sober. And, well, yes, maybe it's just a little boring.

results.abstract: Timothy Egan Op-Ed column holds that in Phoenix, Ariz, where temperature reaches 110 degrees, summer is winter in sense that residents stay indoors hunkered inside climate-controlled world; maintains that innovation cannot bring alpine air to streets unless you put dome over whole city (M)
results.snippet: If you live in Phoenix, you know what it means when the sun becomes an enemy.
results.lead_paragraph: Every week, more than 2,000 people move to the Valley of Sun, to a metro area nearly as big in size as the state of New Jersey. They come from Pittsburgh, from Buffalo, from Cleveland, from Fargo -- from yesterday to tomorrow. A city equal to Rochester plants itself here every two years. And what they find is a compelling urban experiment: nearly four million people trying to live in the Sonoran Desert, and live with what they had at home -- golf courses, lakes, perennial green. But they also learn that summer is winter, in the sense that Phoenicians stay indoors this time of year, hunkered inside a climate-controlled world, and plan their extended midday excursions like an astronaut going for a space walk. In the stillness of late-afternoon, you wonder: where is everybody?

results.abstract: NASA waves off two landing opportunities for space shuttle Atlantis at Kennedy Space Center because of rain and clouds (M)

headline.main: Rain and Clouds Make NASA Cancel Shuttle Landing

results.snippet: Rain and clouds forced NASA to wave off two landing opportunities for the space shuttle Atlantis Thursday afternoon.     Instead, Atlantis' mission, originally scheduled for 11 days, has entered its fourteenth day.
results.lead_paragraph: Rain and clouds forced NASA to wave off two landing opportunities for the space shuttle Atlantis Thursday afternoon. Instead, Atlantis' mission, originally scheduled for 11 days, has entered its fourteenth day.

results.abstract: Donald A Lykkebak, lawyer for Lisa M Nowak, says that she did not wear diapers during her 950-mile road trip to confront romantic rival (S)
results.snippet: The astronaut Lisa M. Nowak did not wear diapers during her 950-mile road trip to confront a romantic rival, her lawyer said.
results.lead_paragraph: The astronaut Lisa M. Nowak did not wear diapers during her 950-mile road trip to confront a romantic rival, her lawyer said Friday, disputing one of the more bizarre details to emerge from a love triangle. ''The biggest lie in this preposterous tale that has been told is that my client drove from Houston, Tex., to Orlando, Fla., nonstop, wearing a diaper,'' the lawyer, Donald A. Lykkebak, told reporters after filing motions here to suppress evidence in his client's criminal case. ''That is an absolute fabrication.''
